title: CRUSADE Score for Post-MI Bleeding Risk
description: Risk stratifies patients with NSTEMI undergoing anticoagulation to determine their risk of major bleeding during hospitalization

parameters.name: creatinine_clearance
parameters.description: Calculated creatinine clearance using Cockcroft-Gault equation

parameters.name: heart_rate
parameters.description: Heart rate on admission in beats per minute

parameters.name: patient_sex
parameters.description: Patient biological sex (female patients have higher bleeding risk)

parameters.name: signs_chf
parameters.description: Signs of congestive heart failure at presentation (dyspnea, rales, elevated JVP, S3 gallop)

parameters.name: diabetes_mellitus
parameters.description: History of diabetes mellitus (Type 1 or Type 2)

parameters.name: prior_vascular_disease
parameters.description: History of prior vascular disease (PAD, cerebrovascular disease, aortic aneurysm)

parameters.name: systolic_blood_pressure
parameters.description: Systolic blood pressure on admission in mmHg

result.name: crusade_score
result.description: Total CRUSADE score ranging from 1-100 points predicting major bleeding risk

ranges.interpretation: CRUSADE score ≤20 indicates very low bleeding risk (3.1% major bleeding rate). Standard antithrombotic therapy is appropriate. Monitor for bleeding but expect low incidence.
CRUSADE score 21-30 indicates low bleeding risk (5.5% major bleeding rate). Standard antithrombotic therapy is appropriate with routine monitoring for bleeding complications.
CRUSADE score 31-40 indicates moderate bleeding risk (8.6% major bleeding rate). Consider reduced-dose antithrombotic therapy and enhanced bleeding monitoring. Balance ischemic vs bleeding risk.
CRUSADE score 41-50 indicates high bleeding risk (11.9% major bleeding rate). Consider reduced-dose antithrombotic regimens, shorter duration therapy, and intensive bleeding monitoring.

CRUSADE score >50 indicates very high bleeding risk (19.5% major bleeding rate). Strongly consider alternative treatment strategies, minimal effective antithrombotic therapy, and very close monitoring.

references: Subherwal S, Bach RG, Chen AY, et al. Baseline risk of major bleeding in non-ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction: the CRUSADE (Can Rapid risk stratification of Unstable angina patients Suppress ADverse outcomes with Early implementation of the ACC/AHA Guidelines) Bleeding Score. Circulation. 2009;119(14):1873-1882.

Abu-Assi E, Raposeiras-Roubin S, Lear P, et al. The risk of bleeding according to the CRUSADE, ACUITY and HAS-BLED scores in acute coronary syndrome patients treated with prasugrel: insights from a four-year registry. Thromb Res. 2013;132(6):652-658.

Ariza-Solé A, Sánchez-Elvira G, Sánchez-Salado JC, et al. CRUSADE bleeding score validation for ST-segment-elevation myocardial infarction undergoing primary percutaneous coronary intervention. Thromb Res. 2013;132(6):652-658.
formula: Sum of weighted points: Hematocrit + Creatinine Clearance + Heart Rate + Sex + CHF Signs + Diabetes + Vascular Disease + Systolic BP
notes: Developed and validated in NSTEMI patients undergoing antithrombotic therapy
Major bleeding defined as: hematocrit drop ≥12%, RBC transfusion (if baseline Hct ≥28%), or RBC transfusion with witnessed bleeding (if baseline Hct <28%)
Score ranges from 1-100 points with higher scores indicating greater bleeding risk
Validated in both NSTEMI and STEMI patients
Should be used in conjunction with ischemic risk assessment for optimal decision-making
Consider patient-specific factors and bleeding history not captured in the score
Useful for selecting appropriate antithrombotic regimens and monitoring intensity
Can guide duration of dual antiplatelet therapy
Female sex independently associated with increased bleeding risk
